Literature Review: The estimation of the size of nonobserved or shadow economies has been a subject of extensive research, employing various methodologies that can broadly be categorized into micro and macro approaches. This literature review focuses on the comparison of these methodologies, specifically the MIMIC (Multiple Indicators Multiple Causes) estimation approaches, micro survey approach, survey technique, and consumption-income gap approach, to assess whether they lead to implausible differences in the estimated size of shadow economies. The review aims to provide a preliminary answer to this question by examining the findings of previous studies and the adjustments made to reconcile differences between macro and micro estimates. Macro approaches, including the MIMIC model, have been critiqued for producing higher estimates of the shadow economy compared to micro approaches. Critics argue that these higher estimates are due to the inclusion of activities not traditionally considered part of the shadow economy, such as voluntary work, do-it-yourself activities, and classical crime activities (Schneider & Enste, 2000). However, proponents of macro approaches argue that these activities are legitimate components of the nonobserved economy and that macro approaches provide a more comprehensive and accurate estimation (Dell'Anno, 2003). The MIMIC approach, in particular, has been highlighted for its ability to model the shadow economy as a latent variable influenced by multiple causes and indicators, offering a dynamic and flexible framework for estimation (Giles & Tedds, 2002). Despite its advantages, the MIMIC model has been criticized for relying on unrealistic assumptions and producing estimates that are significantly higher than those obtained through micro survey approaches (Breusch, 2005). However, recent studies have shown that when adjustments are made for double-counting and the inclusion of non-traditional activities, the estimates from the MIMIC approach align more closely with those from micro approaches (Schneider & Buehn, 2012). Micro survey approaches, on the other hand, rely on direct data collection methods, such as household surveys and tax audits, to estimate the size of the shadow economy. These approaches are praised for their ability to provide detailed and specific information on shadow economy activities (Williams & Windebank, 1998). However, they are also criticized for their potential underestimation due to the reluctance of respondents to disclose illegal or informal activities (Thomas, 1999). The consumption-income gap approach, another micro method, estimates the shadow economy by analyzing discrepancies between reported income and consumption levels. While this method offers a straightforward estimation technique, it has been critiqued for its inability to distinguish between shadow economy activities and other factors that may cause discrepancies, such as measurement errors (Pissarides & Weber, 1989). In conclusion, while macro and micro approaches to estimating the size of the shadow economy have their respective strengths and weaknesses, recent adjustments and methodological refinements have helped to reconcile the differences between them. The MIMIC approach, in particular, has shown that with appropriate adjustments, it can provide estimates that are comparable to those obtained through micro survey approaches. This suggests that claims of implausible differences in the size of the shadow economy estimated by different methods may be overstated and that a more nuanced understanding of the methodologies and their applications is necessary.
